text: Please use Issues page questions guidelines. can also submit preliminary pull request questions.

title: Contributing to iheatmapr
text: contributing iheatmapr, expected follow code conduct.

iheatmapr R package building complex, interactive heatmaps using modular building blocks. “Complex” heatmaps heatmaps subplots along rows columns main heatmap add information row column. example, one column additional heatmap may indicate group particular row column belongs . Complex heatmaps may also include multiple side side heatmaps show different types data conditions. Interactivity can improve complex heatmaps providing tooltips information cell enabling zooming interesting features. already plenty awesome R packages making heatmaps, including several great packages making relatively simple interactive heatmaps (heatmaply d3heatmap) complex static heatmaps (ComplexHeatmap), iheatmapr seeks make easy make complex interactive heatmaps. vignette, use Indometh data included datasets package. data set contains data pharmacokinetics Indometacin, specifically observed plasma concentration indometacin various time points intravenous injection 6 different patients. first cast data matrix concentrations patients (rows) time (columns). also compute correlation matrices patients, maximum minimum concentration Indometacin per patient. Finally, assign patients groups – dataset extra patient information provided ’ll just make arbitrary groups intended show one might use actual groupings like gender ethnicity.
code: library(iheatmapr) library(datasets) library(reshape2)  Indometh_matrix <- acast(Indometh, Subject ~ time, value.var = "conc") Indometh_matrix <- Indometh_matrix[as.character(1:6),] rownames(Indometh_matrix) <- paste("Patient",rownames(Indometh_matrix)) Indometh_patient_cor <- cor(t(Indometh_matrix))  patient_max_conc <- apply(Indometh_matrix,1,max) patient_min_conc <- apply(Indometh_matrix,1,min) patient_groups <- c("A","A","B","A","B","A") # Arbitrary groups

text: start showing example type complex heatmap can create using iheatmapr package. example complex heatmap, plot: heatmap correlation matrix dendrogram column clustering dendrogram row clustering well annotation heatmap showing 3 clusters annotation heatmaps showing max min Indometacin concentrations per patient annotation heatmap showing whether patients fall group “” “B” heatmap showing actual Indometacin timecourse data patient plot showing average Indometacin timecourse response titles labels heatmaps plots aligned correlation heatmap horizontally share y axis thus zooming y direction within heatmap also zoom subplots. plots aligned either correlation heatmap concentration heatmap vertically share x axis heatmap zooming horizontally within plots linked. Hovering heatmaps yields tooltip name row column well value represented.
code:
main_heatmap(Indometh_patient_cor,name = "Correlation") %>% add_col_clustering() %>% add_row_clustering(k = 3) %>% add_row_title("Patients") %>% add_col_title("Patients") %>% add_row_annotation(data.frame("Max" = patient_max_conc, "Min" = patient_min_conc, "Groups" = patient_groups)) %>% add_main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix, name = "Indometacin
Concentration") %>% add_col_labels() %>% add_col_title("Time") %>% add_col_summary()

text: initialize heatmap using main_heatmap can specify row / column order using row_order col_order arguments respectively. functions add_row_clustering add_col_clustering (See Add clustering) can also used order rows columns. row column order specified (either initially later function), ordering carried plots along axis.

iheatmapr package includes two functions, iheatmap add_iheatmap, wrap together several modular building blocks often used conjunction make common types heatmaps. Rather calling many modular functions individually, additional arguments can passed iheatmap add_iheatmap. modular subcomponents can specified way, components can still added directly function calls (e.g. add_col_summary). following code generates plot first example heatmap : functions can useful quickly creating fairly standard plot. However, fewer options available iheatmap using modular functions much less flexibility ordering sizing different subcomponents.
code:
iheatmap(Indometh_patient_cor, cluster_cols = "hclust", cluster_rows = "hclust", col_title = "Patients", row_title = "Patients", name = "Correlation", row_k = 3, row_annotation = data.frame("Max" = patient_max_conc, "Min" = patient_min_conc, "Groups" = patient_groups)) %>% add_iheatmap(Indometh_matrix, name = "Indometacin
Concentration", # html
tag used to split lines col_title = "Time", col_labels = TRUE) %>% add_col_summary()

text: save_iheatmap function can used save iheatmap object standalone html file static pdf/png/jpeg.
code: myplot <- iheatmap(Indometh_patient_cor,           cluster_cols = "hclust",           cluster_rows = "hclust",          col_title = "Patients",          name = "Correlation")   myplot %>% save_iheatmap("myplot.html") # Save interactive HTML myplot %>% save_iheatmap("myplot.pdf") # Save static plot (pdf, png, or jpeg)

text: section vignette, explore modular components included iheatmapr package.

main_heatmap function creates basic heatmap. default, column row names input matrix used determining “Row” “Column” labels tooltip cell. Alternatively one can provide “y” “x” arguments use different labels tooltip. Providing arguments also affect row column labels added later (See Add labels) change color use “colors” argument either name RColorBrewer palette vector colors:
code: main_heatmap(Indometh_patient_cor,               name = "Correlation") patient_names <- paste0("Patient ",seq_len(ncol(Indometh_patient_cor)))  main_heatmap(Indometh_patient_cor,               x = patient_names,              y = patient_names,              name = "Correlation") main_heatmap(Indometh_patient_cor,              colors = "Blues",              name = "Correlation")

text: add_main_heatmap function similar main heatmap function, just adds new main heatmap left right existing plots. Note “name” argument given first main heatmap additional main heatmap, two heatmaps share colorscale colorbar. See Orientation adding main heataps vertically instead horizontally!
code:
main_heatmap(Indometh_patient_cor, name = "Correlation") %>% add_main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix, name = "Indometacin
Concentration")

text: Row column labels shown default. add , use add_row_labels add_col_labels. default, use row column names provided main_heatmap add_main_heatmap either directly indirectly via row column names matrix.
code: main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix, name = "Correlation") %>%   add_row_labels() %>%    add_col_labels() %>%    add_row_title("Patients") %>%    add_col_title("Patients")

text: functions add_row_clustering add_col_clustering cluster rows columns. default, clustering via hierarchical clustering dendrogram added. Specifying value k result cluster assignments made based dendrogram annotation heatmap gets added showing clustering. Alternatively, clustering can done using kmeans setting method = "kmeans". case, value k must given! Another way clustering results giving group assignments.
code: main_heatmap(Indometh_patient_cor) %>%    add_row_clustering() %>%    add_col_clustering() main_heatmap(Indometh_patient_cor) %>%    add_row_clustering(k = 3) %>%    add_col_clustering() main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>%    add_row_clustering(k = 3, method = "kmeans") main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>%    add_row_clustering(method = "groups", groups = c("A","A","B","B","A","A"))

text: functions add_row_clustering add_col_clustering perform clustering based options given. However, might cases want control clustering able ensure clustering matches analysis visualization. give control clustering, two lower-level functions take clustering result simply add plot. hierarchical clustering, can use add_row_dendro add_col_dendro functions add dendrogram. clustering result provided “hclust” object. want add dendrogram already ordered matrix, can set “reorder” argument FALSE. adding cluster assignments method like K-means, add_col_clusters add_row_clusters functions can used. functions take vector cluster assignments add annotation heatmap showing assignments also re-order rows columns based clustering. add_row_clusters add_col_clusters methods similar add_col_groups add_col_groups; main difference add_row_clusters dd_col_clusters also reorder rows columns addition adding annotation heatmap.
code: clust_res <- hclust(as.dist(1 - Indometh_patient_cor))  main_heatmap(Indometh_patient_cor) %>%    add_row_dendro(clust_res) %>%   add_col_dendro(clust_res) clust_assign <- kmeans(Indometh_matrix, 3)$cluster  main_heatmap(Indometh_patient_cor) %>%    add_row_clusters(clust_assign) %>%   add_col_clusters(clust_assign)

text: functions add_row_annotation add_col_annotation add one annotation heatmaps. Annotations provided data.frame something can coerced data.frame. default, colors chosen annotation. assign colors , provide list colors, names list matching column names annotation. Colors can either name RColorBrewer palette vector colors. control annotation heatmaps, use functions add_col_signal add_row_signal adding single continuous annotation add_col_groups add_row_groups adding single discrete annotation.
code:
main_heatmap(Indometh_patient_cor) %>% add_row_annotation(data.frame("Max" = patient_max_conc, "Min" = patient_min_conc, "Groups" = c("A","A","B","B","A","A"))) main_heatmap(Indometh_patient_cor) %>% add_row_annotation(data.frame("Max" = patient_max_conc, "Min" = patient_min_conc, "Groups" = c("A","A","B","B","A","A")), colors = list("Max" = "Reds", "Min" = "Blues", "Groups" = c("purple","pink"))) main_heatmap(Indometh_patient_cor) %>% add_row_signal(patient_max_conc, "Max
Concentration", title = "Max", colors = "Reds") %>% add_row_signal(patient_min_conc, "Min
Concentration", title = "Min", colors = "Reds") %>% add_row_groups(c("A","A","B","B","A","A"), "Groups")

text: One type subplot can added summary values rows columns. example plotting Indometh concentrations per patient time might want plot average time response using add_col_summary. add_row_summary similar adds plot along left summarizing rows. add_col_summary add_row_summary can pass groups divide rows columns respectively computing summary: groups set TRUE rather vector groups, function try use existing set groups clusters added plot. avoided one set groups added (one existing sets groups used case.) default, summarization done using mean. However, summary_function argument can set ‘median’, ‘sd’, ‘var’, ‘mad’, ‘max’, ‘min’, ‘sum’ order perform alternate summarizations (Note: ‘sum’ introduced v0.4.4). can also use layout argument pass title new axis.
code: main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>%    add_col_summary() main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>%    add_col_summary(groups = c("A","A","B","B","A","A")) main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>%    add_row_clustering(k = 3) %>%    add_col_summary(groups = TRUE) main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>%    add_row_clustering(k = 3) %>%    add_col_summary(summary_function = "sd",                    layout = list(title = "sd"))

text: functions add_col_barplot add_row_barplot add barplots along columns rows main heatmap.
code: main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>%    add_col_barplot(y = as.numeric(colnames(Indometh_matrix)),                   tracename = "time",                    layout = list(title = "Time"))

text: functions add_col_barplot add_row_barplot add line plot along columns rows main heatmap.
code: main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>%    add_col_plot(y = as.numeric(colnames(Indometh_matrix)),                   tracename = "time",                    layout = list(title = "Time"))

text: functions adding barplots lineplots assume one data point per row column. add arbitrary plot, one can use add_subplot.
code: main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>%    add_subplot(x = 1:3, y = 4:6, side = "top")

text: next section vignette cover customization options available iheatmapr.

iheatmapr tries choose colors automatically sensible way. heatmap “name” argument another heatmap added, two heatmaps share colorbar scale. Functions make add heatmaps subplots “colors” argument can used specify colors manually. arguments take RColorBrewer palette names vectors colors. example, simply repeat exact main heatmap “name” argument column names annotation matrices, colorbars duplicated.
code: main_heatmap(Indometh_patient_cor, name = "Correlation") %>%   add_row_annotation(data.frame("Max" = patient_max_conc,                                 "Min" = patient_min_conc,                                 "Groups" = c("A","A","B","B","A","A")),                      colors = list("Max" = "Reds",                                    "Min" = "Blues",                                    "Groups" = c("purple","pink"))) %>% add_main_heatmap(Indometh_patient_cor, name = "Correlation") %>%   add_row_annotation(data.frame("Max" = patient_max_conc,                                 "Min" = patient_min_conc,                                 "Groups" = c("A","A","B","B","A","A")),                      colors = list("Max" = "Reds",                                    "Min" = "Blues",                                    "Groups" = c("purple","pink")))

text: additional heatmaps annotations colorscales added iheatmap object, colorbars added according grid pattern. layout spacing grid can specified using “colorbar_grid” parameter iheatmap simple_heatmap. default, grid three rows. change layout grid 2 rows adjust spacing sizing colorbars, can use function setup_colorbar_grid create ColorbarGridParameters object can passed colorbar_grid argument simple_heatmap.
code:
grid_params <- setup_colorbar_grid(nrows = 2, y_length = 0.3, x_spacing = 0.2, y_spacing = 0.5, x_start = 1.1, y_start = 1) iheatmap(Indometh_patient_cor, cluster_cols = "hclust", cluster_rows = "hclust", col_title = "Patients", name = "Correlation", row_k = 3, row_annotation = data.frame("Max" = patient_max_conc, "Min" = patient_min_conc, "Groups" = patient_groups), colorbar_grid = grid_params) %>% add_iheatmap(Indometh_matrix, name = "Indometacin
Concentration", # html
tag used to split lines col_title = "Time", row_title = "Patients") %>% add_col_summary()

text: plots , axes main heatmaps treated categorical, columns equal widths rows equal widths. cases, may make sense treat one axes continuous. several ways indicate iheatmapr axes continuous. first use x_categorical y_categorical arguments, setting false. default, names rows columns taken row column names matrix, respectively. Alternatively, can provided x y arguments main_heatmap iheatmap. values given numeric correspond simply row column number, axis assumed continuous.
code: main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix, x_categorical = FALSE) main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix, x = as.numeric(colnames(Indometh_matrix)))

text: Labels bit different continuous axes – rather labelling every row column, labels chosen similarly regular plot.
code: main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix, x_categorical = FALSE) %>%   add_col_labels()

text: Another major difference categorical axes continuous axes can’t clustered!
code: main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix, x_categorical = FALSE) %>%   add_col_clustering() # will give error ## Error in .local(p, ...): Cannot cluster continuous axis!

text: default, additional heatmaps added horizontally left right existing heatmap(s). also possible build complex heatmaps vertically rather horizontally setting orientation = vertical initial call iheatmap main_heatmap.
code:
iheatmap(Indometh_patient_cor, cluster_cols = "hclust", cluster_rows = "hclust", row_title = "Patients", name = "Correlation", orientation = "vertical") %>% add_iheatmap(t(Indometh_matrix), name = "Indometacin
Concentration", # html
tag used to split lines row_title = "Time", col_title = "Patients")

text: General plotly layout arguments can passed layout argument main_heatmap iheatmap. See plotly documentation information various options. layout can also adjusted creation plot using modify_layout function.
code: main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix, layout = list(margin = list(b = 120))) main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>% modify_layout(list(margin = list(b = 120)))

text: functions adding subplot include “layout” argument providing layout parameters additional axis created. layout parameter accepts list layout parameters plotly uses altering layout axis. See plotly documentation information various options. example, plot default axis options: Adding zeroline = FALSE removes zero line, title = "Average" adds yaxis label.
code:
iheatmap(Indometh_matrix, name = "Indometacin
Concentration", # html
tag used to split lines col_title = "Time", row_title = "Patients") %>% add_col_summary() iheatmap(Indometh_matrix, name = "Indometacin
Concentration", # html
tag used to split lines col_title = "Time", row_title = "Patients") %>% add_col_summary(layout = list(zeroline = FALSE, title = "Average"))

text: default subplots stacked vertically share X axis main heatmap, subplots stacked horizontally share Y axis main heatmap. Subplots can also made share axis existing subplot. example two subplots independent axes: passing “yname” argument axes, axes become shared:
code: main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>%   add_col_summary() %>%   add_main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>%   add_col_summary() main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>%   add_col_summary(yname = "Summary") %>%   add_main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>%   add_col_summary(yname = "Summary")

text: type subplot default relative size default relative spacing previous plots, size spacing can altered passing ‘buffer’ ‘size’ argument. arguments relative size first main heatmap along dimension.
code: main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>%   add_col_summary() main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix) %>%   add_col_summary(buffer = 0.2, size = 1)

text: change sizing within knitr, use fig.width fig.height chunk options.

Iheatmap objects can used shiny. renderIheatmap function used server code, iheatmaprOutput ui code. observing events, iheatmapr_event function used. function takes first argument Iheatmap object, second argument type event – “click”,“hover”, “relayout”. see output iheatmapr_event, can use shiny_test function iheatmapr. see code demo shiny app:
code:
hm <- main_heatmap(Indometh_patient_cor,name = "Correlation") %>% add_col_clustering() %>% add_row_clustering(k = 3) %>% add_row_title("Patients") %>% add_col_title("Patients") %>% add_row_annotation(data.frame("Max" = patient_max_conc, "Min" = patient_min_conc, "Groups" = patient_groups)) %>% add_main_heatmap(Indometh_matrix, name = "Indometacin
Concentration") %>% add_col_labels() %>% add_col_title("Time") %>% add_col_summary() ## NOT RUN (runs shiny app) test_iheatmapr_event(hm, "click") test_iheatmapr_event ## function (ihm, event = c("click", "hover", "relayout")) ## { ## if (!requireNamespace("shiny", quietly = TRUE)) ## stop("shiny not installed") ## event <- match.arg(event) ## ui <- shiny::fluidPage(shiny::titlePanel("iheatmapr event example"), ## shiny::fluidRow(shiny::column(8, iheatmaprOutput("heat")), ## shiny::column(4, shiny::verbatimTextOutput("cl")))) ## server <- function(input, output) { ## output$heat <- renderIheatmap({ ## ihm ## }) ## output$cl <- shiny::renderPrint({ ## s <- iheatmapr_event(ihm, event) ## if (is.null(s) == TRUE) ## return(paste0(event, " to see output")) ## utils::str(s) ## }) ## } ## shiny::shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server) ## } ## ##

title: Interactive, Complex Heatmaps
text: iheatmapr R package building complex, interactive heatmaps using modular building blocks. “Complex” heatmaps heatmaps subplots along rows columns main heatmap add information row column. example, one column additional heatmap may indicate group particular row column belongs . Complex heatmaps may also include multiple side side heatmaps show different types data conditions. Interactivity can improve complex heatmaps providing tooltips information cell enabling zooming interesting features. iheatmapr uses plotly library interactivity. already plenty awesome R packages making heatmaps, including several great packages making relatively simple interactive heatmaps (heatmaply d3heatmap) complex static heatmaps (ComplexHeatmap), iheatmapr seeks make easy make complex interactive heatmaps.

title: Interactive, Complex Heatmaps
text: install CRAN version iheatmapr: install github version iheatmapr:
code: install.packages("iheatmapr") devtools::install_github("ropensci/iheatmapr")

title: Interactive, Complex Heatmaps
text: example complex heatmap, can make version famous vaccines plot Wall Street Journal recreated several heatmap frameworks R.  code create heatmap : Modular components plot added iterative fashion top, right, left, bottom heatmap. iheatmapr also contains function (iheatmap) make fairly standard heatmap optional dendrograms row column annotation heatmaps (See vignette). plots aligned main heatmap horizontally share y axis thus zooming y direction within heatmap also zoom subplots. plots aligned vertically share x axis heatmap zooming horizontally within plots linked. Hovering heatmaps yields tooltip name row column well value represented.
code:
library(iheatmapr) data(measles, package = "iheatmapr") main_heatmap(measles, name = "Measles
Cases", x_categorical = FALSE, layout = list(font = list(size = 8))) %>% add_col_groups(ifelse(1930:2001 < 1961,"No","Yes"), side = "bottom", name = "Vaccine
Introduced?", title = "Vaccine?", colors = c("lightgray","blue")) %>% add_col_labels(ticktext = seq(1930,2000,10),font = list(size = 8)) %>% add_row_labels(size = 0.3,font = list(size = 6)) %>% add_col_summary(layout = list(title = "Average
across
states"), yname = "summary") %>% add_col_title("Measles Cases from 1930 to 2001", side= "top") %>% add_row_summary(groups = TRUE, type = "bar", layout = list(title = "Average
per
year", font = list(size = 8)))

Additionally, numerous people Genentech helped provide feedback guidance project, including limited Justin Finkle, August Guang, Michael Lawrence, Gabe Becker, Steve Lianoglou, Pete Haverty… thanks helped review code /provide feedback! package also went -boarding process rOpensci – thanks reviewers Carl Ganz Andee Kaplan editor Maëlle Salmon helpful feedback!
